author: jgm
content:
Well the story to date that I have seen has been that Ether is the same underlying asset for both Ethereum 1 and Ethereum 2.  Furthermore, at the point that Ethereum 1 becomes an EE in Ethereum 2 Ether will be fungible regardless of it it moved over to Ethereum 2 via the deposit contract or the EE state shift.  If this happens then being separate currencies before that point would cause serious upset to the community as one version of Ether would lose value compared to the other.

I'm not saying that we must have a two-way bridge; I understand the difficulties involved.  But if we want people to stake Ether it has to be as easy as possible, and doing as much as we can to support the "its all Ether" argument on the technical side is important.  And progress towards a two-way bridge, both theoretical and practical, can only help.

author: cdetrio

And I don't think a 2-way bridge would happen any sooner.   hmmm... the "bridge versus switchover" debate is beginning to feel a bit like "ProgPow vs PoS" hehe

author: jgm
content: If we end up in a situation where the two-way bridge is abandoned because the switchover HF occurs that's fine; it's more about direction of travel being clearly "it's all Ether" rather than talking about ETH Vs. bETH or whatever
